text:
Situation A. Jelani and Aida Use Graphs and Equations

Jelani's Graph: "I drew the following graph to help me find the number of cakes sold to make a profit. "
Aida's Equation: I can find the coordinates of the point of intersection by solving the following equation:

Yes.

Jelani's Graph:

Jelani can find when the bakery's expenses and income are approximately equal. Where the lines intersect, we know that the bakery will make $0. After than, it will begin to make a profit.

Aida's Equation:

This is possible because (8.20n) represents the income and (825 + 3.25n) represents the expenses. So by solving the equation, you are finding the point when income and expenses are equal, or where the two lines intersect.
• Jelani highlighted the vertical distance –330 between the two graphs. What does the 330 represent on the graph? What does it represent in the real world?

The 330 shows that the value of E is higher than I. In the real world, this shows that the bakery will spend $330 more in expenses than he will earn when he sells 100 cakes.

This could be represented with -330 because income is less than expenses. So it could be considered owing or being in debt.
• If the bakery sells 125 cakes, is he losing or making money? Explain why.
Losing. Looking at the graphs, income (pink line) is lower than the expenses (blue line) until after 166 2/3 cakes. So, he will lose money until he sells more than 166 2/3 cakes.
Note: Students may have discussed this in the Initial Challenge.
• Fabian uses the equation P = Income – Expenses to predict the profit P. He wrote P = 8.20n – (825 + 3.25n). Does this make sense? Explain.
Yes, since he wants to subtract expenses from income for a given number of cakes, he can subtract the expenses expression from the income expression to give an expression for overall profit.
• Adia rewrites Fabian’s profit equation as P = 4.95n – 825. Is she correct? Explain.
Yes, this equation will give the same result as Fabian’s. Her equation gives the profit for each cake and subtracts the fixed, monthly expenses.

Situation C. Fabian’s Profit Inequality

Fabian and Charlotte are looking for ways to express how to find the number of cakes needed to make a profit. Explain why each representation does or does not make sense.

The inequality statement does make sense, because it says that they want their profit to be greater than their income – expenses. The number line does make sense because it shows all possible values of n for which it has a profit.
